message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Imprinting is the phenomenon where one allele is silenced during development, leading to expression of only the other allele. This can explain why the patient is affected despite having a normal allele. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern requires only one copy of the mutated allele to be affected, and locus heterogeneity and uniparental disomy involve mutations at different loci or from one parent, respectively, neither of which is described in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Imprinting refers to when one allele is silenced or expressed differently based on whether it was inherited from the mother or the father. In this case, the mutated allele may be imprinted and not silenced, leading to the patient’s symptoms despite having one normal allele. Autosomal dominant inheritance would require both alleles to be mutated, while locus heterogeneity and uniparental disomy do not explain the phenomenon of one normal allele and one affected allele.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has Prader-Willi syndrome, which occurs due to loss of function of genes on the paternally inherited chromosome 15q11-q13 region. This occurs via genomic imprinting, in which gene expression is influenced by the parent of origin. Therefore, despite having a normal allele, the abnormal expression of the paternal allele leads to the patient’s condition. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, locus heterogeneity, and uniparental disomy are not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Imprinting is when a gene is expressed differently depending on which parent it comes from. In this case, the mutated allele is likely imprinted and only the normal allele is being expressed, but it is not enough to prevent the patient from being affected. This is consistent with the severe obesity and hypogonadism seen in the patient. Autosomal dominant inheritance, locus heterogeneity, and uniparental disomy are not likely explanations in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Imprinting is a phenomenon where genes from only one parent are active, while the other parent's genes are silent. In this case, it is likely that the mutated allele is on the active parent's gene, while the normal allele is on the silent parent's gene, leading to the patient being affected despite having a normal allele. This is an example of genomic imprinting, which can result in unusual inheritance patterns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's phenotype is suggestive of Prader-Willi syndrome, which is caused by a loss of function of genes from the paternal chromosome 15q11.2-q13 due to imprinting. In this syndrome, only the maternal allele is expressed and the paternal allele is silenced. The patient in this question has only one mutated allele, but because of imprinting, the normal allele from the father is not expressed, leading to the patient's phenotype. This is a classic example of imprinting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of one mutated allele and one normal allele suggests an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. However, the presence of imprinting (where one allele is silenced depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or father) can cause a disorder even with one mutated allele. This is the most likely explanation for this patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Imprinting is the most likely explanation for why this patient is affected despite having a normal allele. Imprinting is an epigenetic phenomenon where one allele is preferentially silenced. In some cases, the imprinted allele may be the only functional allele, leading to disease, even if the other allele is normal. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, locus heterogeneity, and uniparental disomy do not explain the specific situation of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has one mutated allele and one normal allele suggests that the inheritance pattern may not be autosomal dominant. Locus heterogeneity refers to mutations in different genes leading to similar phenotypes, which is not the case here. Uniparental disomy is when both copies of a chromosome come from one parent, which is also not applicable in this case. Imprinting is the most likely explanation as it refers to the differential expression of genes depending on whether they are inherited from the mother or the father. In this case, the mutated allele may be on the paternal chromosome, which is silenced due to imprinting, leaving only the mutated allele on the maternal chromosome expressed. This can result in the patient being affected despite having one normal allele.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The severe obesity and hypogonadism suggest that the gene of interest is located on the X chromosome. Imprinting refers to the phenomenon where only one allele is expressed based on whether it was inherited from the mother or father. Therefore, even with one normal allele, if the mutated allele is the one that is expressed due to imprinting, the patient can still be affected. Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and locus heterogeneity both require two mutated alleles to be present. Uniparental disomy refers to the inheritance of two copies of the same chromosome from one parent, which is not relevant in this case.
